instructions: Answer all questions about data types, measurement errors, variables, and reliability. Choose the best answer.

questions.question: Which is an example of qualitative data?
options: The liquid is blue and smells sweet
questions.explanation: Qualitative data describes qualities using words (colour, smell, texture). Quantitative data uses numbers and measurements.

questions.question: Measuring the exact height of a plant in centimetres gives:
questions.explanation: Quantitative data involves numerical measurements that can be counted or measured objectively.

questions.question: A digital balance shows 0.4 g when the pan is empty. This is:
questions.explanation: Zero error occurs when an instrument does not read zero when nothing is being measured. Always check and correct for zero error before taking measurements.

questions.question: Parallax error happens when you:
options: Read a measuring cylinder from an angle instead of eye level
questions.explanation: Always position your eye level with the scale (e.g., bottom of meniscus in liquids) to avoid parallax error.

questions.question: In an experiment testing how fertilizer affects plant height, the plant height is the:
questions.explanation: The dependent variable is what you measure (plant height). The independent variable is what you change (fertilizer amount).

questions.question: To make a test fair when testing ramp steepness on toy car speed, you must keep these the SAME:
options: Car type, ramp surface, starting point
questions.explanation: Controlled variables (like car type, surface) must stay constant so only the independent variable (steepness) affects results.

questions.question: Reliability of results is improved by:
options: Changing two variables at the same time
Repeating trials and calculating the average
questions.explanation: Repeating experiments reduces random errors. Reliable results are consistent across multiple trials.

questions.question: A student measures the mass of a 50.0 g standard weight three times and gets: 48.2 g, 48.3 g, 48.1 g. These measurements are:
questions.explanation: The measurements are close to each other (precise) but far from the true value of 50.0 g (not accurate). This suggests a systematic error like zero error.

questions.question: The same 50.0 g weight is measured by another student who gets: 49.8 g, 50.3 g, 50.1 g. These measurements are:
questions.explanation: Measurements are close to each other (precise) AND close to 50.0 g (accurate). The average (50.1 g) is very near the true value.

questions.question: A ruler shows 2 mm at the 'zero' end when its ends are aligned. Before measuring, you should:
options: Use only the middle part of the ruler
questions.explanation: This is zero error. If the ruler starts at 2 mm instead of 0 mm, subtract 2 mm from every measurement to get the true length.

questions.question: Reading the meniscus of water in a measuring cylinder from above causes:
options: Parallax error giving a higher volume reading
Parallax error giving a lower volume reading
No error if you estimate carefully
questions.explanation: Viewing from above makes the meniscus appear higher, leading to an overestimation of volume. Always read at eye level with the bottom of the meniscus.

questions.question: Student A measures a 10.0 cm object five times and gets: 9.2 cm, 10.8 cm, 8.9 cm, 11.1 cm, 10.0 cm. Student B gets: 9.4 cm, 9.5 cm, 9.3 cm, 9.4 cm, 9.5 cm. Which statement is TRUE?
options: Student B is more precise but less accurate
questions.explanation: Student B's measurements are very close to each other (precise) but average to 9.4 cm (not accurate). Student A's measurements are scattered (not precise) but average to 10.0 cm (accurate).

questions.question:
Three groups measure the boiling point of water (true value = 100°C at sea level):
Group X: 100.1°C, 100.2°C, 100.0°C
Group Y: 98.5°C, 98.6°C, 98.4°C
Group Z: 95.0°C, 102.0°C, 103.0°C
Which group has the MOST RELIABLE results?
questions.explanation: Reliability = consistency across repeated trials. Group X has the smallest spread (most consistent), so most reliable. Group Y is precise but inaccurate (systematic error). Group Z is neither precise nor accurate.

questions.question: Which action improves the accuracy of measuring liquid volume?
options: Reading the meniscus at eye level
Using a beaker instead of a measuring cylinder
questions.explanation: Reading at eye level eliminates parallax error, improving accuracy. Repeating improves reliability/precision, not accuracy. Beakers are less accurate than measuring cylinders.

questions.question: Recording 'the solution felt warm' is:
questions.explanation: Describing sensations (warm, colour, smell) is qualitative. For quantitative: 'Temperature rose by 12°C'.
